      Methods in stormpot with parameters of type PoolFixture 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void PoolTest.awaitCompletionWithNullTimeUnitMustThrow(PoolFixture fixture)
      One must provide a Timeout argument when awaiting the completion of a shut-down procedure.
      void PoolTest.awaitCompletionWithTimeoutLessThanOneMustReturnImmediately(PoolFixture fixture)
      When await is called on a shutdown Completion with a timeout value less than one, then no amount of waiting must take place.
      void PoolTest.awaitingOnAlreadyCompletedShutDownMustNotBlock(PoolFixture fixture)
      We have verified that the await method works as intended, if you begin your awaiting while the shut down process is still undergoing.
      void PoolTest.awaitOnCompletionWhenInterruptedMustClearInterruption(PoolFixture fixture)
      As per the contract of throwing an InterruptedException, if the await of an unfinished completion throws an InterruptedException, then they must also clear the interrupted status.
      void PoolTest.awaitOnCompletionWhenInterruptedMustThrow(PoolFixture fixture)
      Calling await on a completion when your thread is interrupted, must throw an InterruptedException.
      void PoolTest.awaitOnFinishedCompletionMustClearInterruption(PoolFixture fixture)
      As per the contract of throwing an InterruptedException, the above must also clear the threads interrupted status.
      void PoolTest.awaitOnShutdownMustReturnWhenClaimedObjectsAreReleased(PoolFixture fixture)
      We know from the previous test, that awaiting the shut down completion will wait for any claimed objects to be released.
      void PoolTest.awaitWithTimeoutMustReturnFalseIfTimeoutElapses(PoolFixture fixture)
      The await with timeout on the Completion of the shut down process must return false if the timeout elapses, as is the typical contract of such methods in java.util.concurrent.
      void PoolTest.awaitWithTimeoutMustReturnTrueIfCompletesWithinTimeout(PoolFixture fixture)
      We have verified that await with timeout returns false if the timeout elapses.
      void PoolTest.awaitWithTimeoutOnCompletionMustThrowUponInterruption(PoolFixture fixture)
      A thread that is awaiting the completion of a shut down procedure with a timeout, must throw an InterruptedException if it is interrupted.
      void PoolTest.awaitWithTimeoutOnFinishedCompletionWhenInterruptedMustThrow(PoolFixture fixture)
      Calling await with a timeout on a finished completion when your thread is interrupted must, just as with calling await without a timeout, throw an InterruptedException.
      void PoolTest.backgroundExpirationMustExpireObjectsWhenExpirationThrows(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.backgroundExpirationMustNotExpireObjectsThatAreClaimed(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.biasedClaimMustUpgradeToOrdinaryClaimIfTheObjectIsPulledFromTheQueue(PoolFixture fixture)
      Pool implementations that do biasing need to ensure, that claimed objects are not available for other threads, even if the object is claimed with a biased kind of claim.
      void PoolTest.blockedClaimMustThrowWhenPoolIsShutDown(PoolFixture fixture)
      A call to claim on a pool that has been, or is in the process of being, shut down, will throw an IllegalStateException.
      void PoolTest.blockedClaimWithTimeoutMustThrowUponInterruption(PoolFixture fixture)
      The claim methods checks whether the current thread is interrupted upon entry, but perhaps what is more important is the interruption of a claim call that is already waiting when the thread is interrupted.
      void PoolTest.blockingClaimWithTimeoutMustWaitIfPoolIsEmpty(PoolFixture fixture)
      If the pool has been depleted for objects, then a call to claim with timeout will wait until either an object becomes available, or the timeout elapses.
      void PoolTest.blockingOnClaimWithTimeoutMustResumeWhenPoolablesAreReleased(PoolFixture fixture)
      A thread that is waiting in claim-with-timeout on a depleted pool must wake up if another thread releases an object back into the pool.
      void PoolTest.callingShutdownMustNotAffectInterruptionStatus(PoolFixture fixture)
      Initiating the shut-down procedure must not influence the threads interruption status.
      void PoolTest.claimMustReturnIfWithinTimeout(PoolFixture fixture)
      A call to claim must return before the timeout elapses if it can claim an object from the pool, and it must return that object.
      void PoolTest.claimMustReturnNullIfTimeoutElapses(PoolFixture fixture)
      A call to claim that fails to get an object before the timeout elapses, must return null.
      void PoolTest.claimMustStayWithinDeadlineEvenIfAllocatorBlocks(PoolFixture fixture)
      A call to claim with time-out must complete within the time-out period even if the Allocator never returns.
      void PoolTest.claimMustStayWithinTimeoutEvenIfExpiredObjectIsReleased(PoolFixture fixture)
      Claim with timeout must adhere to its timeout value.
      void PoolTest.claimMustThrowIfAllocationReturnsNull(PoolFixture fixture)
      Allocators must never return <code>null</code>, and if they do, then a call to claim must throw a PoolException to indicate this fact.
      void PoolTest.claimMustThrowIfReallocationReturnsNull(PoolFixture fixture)
      Reallocators must never return <code>null</code> from Reallocator.reallocate(Slot, Poolable), and if they do, then a call to claim must throw a PoolException to indicate this fact.
      void PoolTest.claimWhenInterruptedMustThrow(PoolFixture fixture)
      Threads that are already interrupted upon entry to the claim method, must promptly be met with an InterruptedException.
      void PoolTest.claimWithTimeoutValueLessThanOneMustReturnImmediately(PoolFixture fixture)
      When claim is called with a timeout less than one, then it means that no (observable amount of) waiting should take place.
      void PoolTest.constructorMustThrowIfConfiguredThreadFactoryReturnsNull(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.constructorMustThrowOnNullAllocator(PoolFixture fixture)
      Prevent the creation of pools with a null Allocator.
      void PoolTest.constructorMustThrowOnNullExpiration(PoolFixture fixture)
      Prevent the creation of pools with a null Expiration.
      void PoolTest.constructorMustThrowOnNullThreadFactory(PoolFixture fixture)
      Prevent the creation of pools with a null ThreadFactory.
      void PoolTest.constructorMustThrowOnPoolSizeLessThanOne(PoolFixture fixture)
      Be careful and prevent the creation of pools with a size less than one.
      void PoolTest.decreasingSizeMustEventuallyDeallocateSurplusObjects(PoolFixture fixture)
      We must somehow ensure that the pool starts deallocating more than it allocates, when the pool is shrunk.
      void PoolTest.depletedPoolThatHasBeenShutDownMustThrowUponClaim(PoolFixture fixture)
      If a pool has been depleted, and then shut down, and another call to claim comes in, then it must immediately throw an IllegalStateException.
      void PoolTest.depletedPoolThatHasBeenShutDownMustThrowUponClaimEvenAfterSomeTime(PoolFixture fixture)
      Basically the same test as above, except now we wait for the shutdown process to make a bit of progress.
      void PoolTest.disabledLeakDetectionMustNotBreakResize(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.exceptionsFromExpirationMustBubbleOut(PoolFixture fixture)
      In the hopefully unlikely event that an Expiration throws an exception, that exception should bubble out of the pool unspoiled.
      void PoolTest.explicitExpiryFromExpirationMustAllowOneClaimPerObject(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.explicitlyExpiryMustBeIdempotent(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.getTargetSizeMustReturnLastSetTargetSize(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.increasingAndDecreasingSizeInQuickSuccessionMustEventuallyReachTargetSize(PoolFixture fixture)
      Make sure that the pool does not get into a bad state, caused by concurrent background resizing jobs interfering with each other.
      void PoolTest.increasingSizeMustAllowMoreAllocations(PoolFixture fixture)
      When we increase the size of a depleted pool, it should be possible to make claim again and get out newly allocated objects.
      void PoolTest.managedPoolLeakedObjectCountMustStartAtZero(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.managedPoolMustAllowGettingAndSettingPoolTargetSize(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.managedPoolMustBeExposableThroughAnMBeanServerAsAnMXBean(PoolFixture fixture)

      void PoolTest.metaTestingAssumptions(PoolFixture ignore) 
      void PoolTest.mustBeAbleToShutDownEvenIfInterrupted(PoolFixture fixture)
      Calling shutdown on a pool while being interrupted must still start the shut-down procedure.
      void PoolTest.mustCheckObjectExpirationInBackgroundWhenEnabled(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustCompleteShutdownEvenIfAllocatorEatsTheInterruptSignal(PoolFixture fixture)
      If the interrupt happen inside the Allocator.allocate(Slot) method, and then the allocator either clears the interruption status, or throws an InterruptedException which in turn will be understood as poison, then the allocation thread can miss the shutdown signal, and never begin the shutdown sequence.
      void PoolTest.mustCompleteShutDownEvenIfAllSlotsHaveAllocationErrors(PoolFixture fixture)
      As with PoolTest.mustCompleteShutDownEvenIfAllSlotsHaveNullErrors(PoolFixture), the pool must be able to shut down if it has never been able to allocate anything.
      void PoolTest.mustCompleteShutDownEvenIfAllSlotsHaveNullErrors(PoolFixture fixture)
      Even if the Allocator has never made a successful allocation, the pool must still be able to complete its shut-down procedure.
      void PoolTest.mustDeallocateAllPoolablesBeforeShutdownTaskReturns(PoolFixture fixture)
      When we call shutdown() on a pool, the shutdown process is initiated and the call returns a Completion object.
      void PoolTest.mustDeallocateExpiredPoolablesAndStayWithinSizeLimit(PoolFixture fixture)
      The size limit on a pool is strict, unless specially (as in a non-standard way) configured otherwise.
      void PoolTest.mustDeallocateExplicitlyExpiredObjects(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustGetPooledObjectsFromAllocator(PoolFixture fixture)
      While the pool mustn’t return null when we claim an object within the timeout period, it likewise mustn’t just come up with any random thing that implements Poolable.
      void PoolTest.mustNotCachePoisonedSlots(PoolFixture fixture)
      Here’s the scenario we’re trying to target:
      void PoolTest.mustNotDeallocateTheSameObjectMoreThanOnce(PoolFixture fixture)
      Clients might hold on to objects after they have been released.
      void PoolTest.mustNotFrivolouslyReallocateNonPoisonedSlotsDuringEagerRecovery(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustNotHoldOnToDeallocatedObjectsWhenLeakDetectionIsDisabled(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustNotHoldOnToDeallocatedObjectsWhenLeakDetectionIsEnabled(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustNotLeakSlotsIfExpirationThrowsThrowableInsteadOfException(PoolFixture fixture)
      The specification only promises to correctly handle Expirations that throw Exceptions, but we also test with Throwable, just in case we might be able to recover from them as well.
      void PoolTest.mustNotReallocateObjectsThatAreNotExpiredByTheBackgroundCheck(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustNotReallocateWhenReleasingExpiredObjectsIntoShrunkPool(PoolFixture fixture)
      Similar to the decreasingSizeMustEventuallyDeallocateSurplusObjects test above, but this time the objects are all expired after the pool has been shrunk.
      void PoolTest.mustNotThrowWhenReleasingObjectClaimedByAnotherThread(PoolFixture fixture)
      It is explicitly permitted that the thread that releases an object back into the pool, can be a different thread than the one that claimed the particular object.
      void PoolTest.mustProactivelyReallocatePoisonedSlotsWhenAllocatorStopsReturningNull(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustProactivelyReallocatePoisonedSlotsWhenAllocatorStopsThrowingExceptions(PoolFixture fixture)

      void PoolTest.mustPropagateExceptionsFromAllocateThroughClaim(PoolFixture fixture)

      void PoolTest.mustPropagateExceptionsFromReallocateThroughClaim(PoolFixture fixture)
      Pools must be prepared in the event that a Reallocator throws an Exception from reallocate.
      void PoolTest.mustReallocateExplicitlyExpiredObjectsInBackgroundWithBackgroundExpiration(PoolFixture fixture)

      Objects in the pool only live for a certain amount of time, and then they must be replaced/renewed.
      void PoolTest.mustReplaceExplicitlyExpiredObjectsEvenIfDeallocationFails(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.mustReuseAllocatedObjects(PoolFixture fixture)
      One uses a pool because a certain type of objects are expensive to create and we would like to recycle them.
      void PoolTest.mustStillBeUsableAfterExceptionInAllocate(PoolFixture fixture)
      A pool must not break its internal invariants if an Allocator throws an exception in allocate, and it must still be usable after the exception has bubbled out.
      void PoolTest.mustStillBeUsableAfterExceptionInReallocate(PoolFixture fixture)
      Likewise as above, a pool must not break its internal invariants if a Reallocator throws an exception in reallocate, and it must still be usable after the exception has bubbled out.
      void PoolTest.mustSwallowExceptionsFromDeallocateThroughRelease(PoolFixture fixture)
      We cannot guarantee that exceptions from deallocating objects will propagate out through release, because the actual deallocation might be done asynchronously in a different thread.
      void PoolTest.mustSwallowExceptionsFromDeallocateThroughShutdown(PoolFixture fixture)
      While it is technically possible to propagate exceptions from an Allocators deallocate method during the shutdown procedure, it would not be a desirable behaviour because it would be inconsistent with how this works for the release method on Poolable - and Slot, for that matter.
      void PoolTest.mustUnbiasObjectsNoLongerClaimed(PoolFixture fixture)
      Pool implementations might do some kind of biasing to reduce contention.
      void PoolTest.mustUseProvidedExpiration(PoolFixture fixture)
      Pools must use the provided expiration to determine whether slots are invalid or not, instead of using their own ad-hoc mechanisms.
      void PoolTest.objectMustBeClaimableAfterBackgroundReallocation(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.poolMustTolerateInterruptedExceptionFromAllocatorWhenNotShutDown(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.poolMustUseConfiguredThreadFactoryWhenCreatingBackgroundThreads(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.poolThatHasBeenShutDownMustThrowUponClaimEvenIfItHasAvailableUnbiasedObjects(PoolFixture fixture)
      We must ensure that, for pool implementation that do biasing, the checking of whether the pool has been shut down must come before even a biased claim.
      void PoolTest.preventClaimFromPoolThatIsShutDown(PoolFixture fixture)
      It is not possible to claim from a pool that has been shut down.
      void PoolTest.settingTargetSizeOnPoolThatHasBeenShutDownDoesNothing(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.shutdownCallMustReturnFastIfPoolablesAreStillClaimed(PoolFixture fixture)
      So awaiting the shut down completion cannot return before all claimed objects are both released and deallocated.
      void PoolTest.shutdownMustEventuallyDeallocateAllPoolables(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.shutdownMustNotDeallocateClaimedPoolables(PoolFixture fixture)
      We have verified that the call to shutdown on a pool does not block on claimed objects, and we have verified that all objects are deallocated when the shut down completes.
      void PoolTest.shutdownMustNotDeallocateEmptySlots(PoolFixture fixture)
      The shutdown procedure might be tempted to blindly iterate the pool data structure and deallocate every possible slot.
      void PoolTest.slotInfoAgeMustResetAfterAllocation(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.slotInfoAgeMustResetAfterReallocation(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.slotInfoClaimCountMustIncreaseWithClaims(PoolFixture fixture)
      SlotInfo objects offer a count of how many times the Poolable it represents, has been claimed.
      void PoolTest.slotInfoClaimCountMustResetIfSlotsAreReused(PoolFixture fixture)
      Pool implementations might reuse their SlotInfo instances.
      void PoolTest.slotInfoMustBeAbleToProduceRandomNumbers(PoolFixture fixture)
      SlotInfo instances must have a means of acting as a non-contended source of random numbers.
      void PoolTest.slotInfoMustHaveAgeInMillis(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.slotInfoMustHaveReferenceToItsPoolable(PoolFixture fixture)
      Expirations might require access to the actual object in question being pooled, in order to implement advanced and/or domain specific logic.
      void PoolTest.slotInfoMustRememberStamp(PoolFixture fixture)
      Verify that we can read back a stamp value from the SlotInfo that we have set, when the Slot has not been re-allocated.
      void PoolTest.slotInfoStampMustResetIfSlotsAreReused(PoolFixture fixture)
      The SlotInfo stamp is zero by default.
      void PoolTest.slotsThatMakeTheExpirationThrowAreInvalid(PoolFixture fixture)
      If the Expiration throws an exception when evaluating a slot, then that slot should be considered invalid.
      void PoolTest.targetSizeMustBeConfiguredSizeByDefault(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.targetSizeMustBeGreaterThanZero(PoolFixture fixture) 
      void PoolTest.throwingInterruptedExceptionFromClaimMustClearInterruptedFlag(PoolFixture fixture)
      As per the general contract of interruptible methods, throwing an InterruptedException will clear the interrupted flag on the thread.
